Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Delay. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Energy consumption. Fig. 3 Unsupervised machine learning based key management in wireless sensor networks D. Sowmyadevi ∗ I. Shanmugapriya Department of Computer Science, PSG College of Arts & Science, India Department of Computer Science PSG College of Arts & Science India Department of Computer Science, PSG College of Arts & Science ∗ Corresponding author. In distributed sensor applications, the secured infrastructure plays a major role in processing and transmission of data. The data transfer in wireless sensor network (WSN) is equipped security measure that prevents the manipulation of data theft by the attackers. The key management protocol offers secured delivery of messages that includes integrity and authenticity via key generation, key distribution and maintenance. In this paper, we develop a lightweight key management protocol (LKMP) that involves reduced memory consumption and processing power. The study uses machine learning algorithm for key management in WSN, and the machine learning uses unsupervised learning mechanism. The simulation is conducted in network simulator and it is compared with existing state-of-the-art models. The results of simulation shows that the proposed method achieves higher rate of throughput, security and resilience than its predecessors. Keywords WSN Security Key management Machine mearning Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The implementation of wireless sensor networks (WSN) is currently experiencing rapid expansion all over the world. Each year sees the publication of much research on WSN technology and standards, some of which are patented while others are open. These research articles investigate a diverse range of topics. Internet of Things (IoT), a considerable number of internet name servers and online service providers have been the targets of botnet attacks in the most recent months [1]. Some manufacturers of IoTdevices are now voluntarily recalling their whole product lines after having their products infiltrated by botnets. Considering this, it is generally agreed upon that the Internet of Things (IoT) and wireless sensor networks (WSN) need to have a high level of security and trustworthiness [2]. A wireless sensor network, also known as a WSN, is comprised of a network of small sensors that are connected to one another and are dispersed in a pattern that is at random. Sensor networks are distinguished from other kinds of computer networks by a variety of characteristics, including their dense location, random deployment, flexible architecture, limited bandwidth, mobile or motionless sensors, and self-configurable sensor nodes [3]. In today environment, information regarding previously inaccessible areas can be gleaned through the utilisation of various sensors. When this kind of information is transferred, it does not typically go through any changes or become corrupted while it is in transit. Threat actors can get around the security of a WSN in a number of different ways by exploiting the large diversity of vulnerabilities that exist in the system. The Internet of Things (IoT) is a network of interconnected, internet-enabled devices that can share data, draw conclusions about their surroundings based on what they sense, and report their findings to the appropriate node in the system. These devices can do all of these things because they are connected to the internet. These devices may also can make predictions about their surroundings based on what they feel inside their immediate environment. Wearables, healthcare, personal care, agriculture, water crisis management, transportation, and other industries are just some of the places where you can discover Internet of Things smart applications that are already in use [4]. Whether or not a wide variety of security threats may be successfully defended against by the network is determined by whether the security criteria for such applications can be met. One of the most damaging forms of attack that can be carried out on a network that is connected to the Internet of Things (IoT) [5], which is vulnerable to a wide variety of different types of denial of service (DoS) attacks, is jamming. This type of attack can be carried out on any network that is connected to the IoT [6,7]. This attack will result in a decline in the performance of the network since it will disconnect channels and prevent the service from being delivered to users who are authorised to receive it. This will cause the performance of the network to decrease. Smart devices have access to a variety of effective encryption mechanisms, which they can utilise to communicate with one another in a secure manner [8]. Despite this, the current key management tactics for the network are ineffective due to the huge amount of energy they consume, the high amount of computing overhead they produce, and the delay they cause. Encryption and good key management are two examples of the kinds of security measures that are vitally necessary when it comes to protecting the environment from the potentially destructive impacts that could be caused by attempts at intrusion [9]. The hash key-based key management strategy that is provided and this makes use of the multi-hop technique to achieve its goals. It is a commonly held belief that the most trustworthy kind of protection for modern wireless networks is provided by security measures that are based on hashes. Cluster-based methods are currently being utilised in the construction of many sensor networks. This is largely being done to improve the energy efficiency as well as the scalability of the system [10]. Within the scope of this investigation, we devise a method of key management that has a low overhead and makes effective use of both the available storage space and the available CPU cycles. This work develops a lightweight key management protocol (LKMP) that involves reduced memory consumption and processing power. After running the simulation through a network simulator, the results are analyzed and compared to the most recent and cutting-edge models that are currently accessible. The findings of the simulation indicate that the proposed method offers improvements over its forerunners in terms of throughput, security, and resilience. 2 Related works This section discusses about the current key management strategy for the cluster-based sensor network, which makes use of secret keys that are produced from a hash function. These keys are kept secret to maintain the network security. A key distribution method for wireless sensor networks that combines a hash chain with deployment knowledge was proposed in Ref. [11] the work that you have done (DKH-KD). To accomplish this, it first determined the total number of hash chains and then generated a pairwise key based on the results of that calculation. To determine the pairwise key, we made use of the values that were produced by a chain of reverse hashes. Due to this, establishing a paired key can be done more quickly and easily, but as a result, the cost of computation can increase due to the process of rekeying. Ehdai et al. [12] presented a method that is based on a 2D hash, and in this technique, the author used two separate hash functions to solve flaws in the security of sensor networks and effectively protect nodes from being seized. The operation ends up reducing the amount of energy that is utilised by a significant margin, but the rekeying process ends up increasing the amount of computing overhead. Jia et al. [13] developed an efficient and lightweight authentication and key management strategy as a means of minimising the required amount of computing expense to produce keys. This computational burden presented itself as a direct consequence of an increase in the number of malicious nodes residing inside the sensor network. The sensor network was plagued by an increase in the number of malicious nodes. The network security has been strengthened, and the amount of work that needs to be done to resolve problems has been cut down significantly. Priyanka et al. [14] provided a technique to key management for wireless sensor networks that was extremely secure and was based on an attack model. The purpose of this method is to build a hash chain to prevent a node capture attack from taking place. Each node in the network contributes to the hash chain by establishing the most fundamental level of security that it thinks is adequate for itself. The first step in calculating the proper level of protection for each cell is to calculate the risk that a cell may be compromised in some way. The solution that was proposed makes a considerable improvement to the network level of security; however, this comes at the expense of an increase in the computational cost, as it calls for a significant number of rekeying processes to be carried out. Ahlawat et al. [15] proposed a hybrid approach for path vulnerability matrices on random key pre-distribution (RKP) for wireless sensor networks to cut down on energy consumption and the possibility of a node capture attempt. This was done to protect the networks from potential intruders trying to take control of the nodes. Mehmood et al. [16] presented a scheme for rekeying and session key agreement in WBAN. The main contribution of this approach has been deployed in both heterogonous and homogenous WSN. A mathematical model validation of this technique, however, will result in better secure model. Ali et al. [17] suggested a WSN cryptography system based on the Diffie-Hellman key exchange. Secure and efficient key generation is achieved by the modified Diffie-Hellman method, which protects against man-in-the-middle attacks. The security operation, key generation, computation time for different data packets, and effective outcomes are all evaluated for this method. However, the proposed method takes a long time to process data responses. These approaches are unable to scale well with a big network since they rely on just one hop to establish the secure connection that needs to be made between sensor nodes. In addition to this, they are not appropriate for use in real-time settings, which renders them inappropriate for usage in any context whatsoever. They are not scalable, and as a result, they are unable to adapt to a dynamic environment that supports mobility characteristics. Consequently, they are unable to support mobility characteristics. In addition, the efficiency of the job that has been completed is not examined in connection with the effect that the attack has had. Both represent significant shortcomings in the previously discussed bodies of work. The constraints caused by the key management approaches that were utilised in the previous work can be avoided by using the proposed research to conduct the investigation. This is performed by determining how well the attack scales in response to the presence of an increasing number of hostile nodes within the network. According to the results of the evaluation, the performance of the network has significantly improved thanks to a reduction in the amount of energy used, the amount of computational cost, and the amount of packet loss. 3 Network model In this section a flat architecture is utilised, all the sensor nodes communicate with one another and share the same resources, including those pertaining to processing, power, and communication. The hierarchical WSN, on the other hand, is composed of a base station (BS) or mobile sink (MS), cluster heads (CHs), and sensor nodes, all of which are organised in a hierarchical structure according to their respective capabilities. The most powerful node in the network is known as the base station. Other nodes in the network are less powerful. The capabilities of storage, transmission, and processing that are made available by CHs are far more advanced as compared to those supplied by sensor nodes, which make up the lowest level of the hierarchy. According to the research presented in Ref. [6], the performance of hierarchical WSNs is superior to that of flat networks in terms of the amount of communication overhead that is experienced as well as the network ability to scale in large-scale contexts. The structure of the methodology that we have proposed is comparable to that of hierarchical WSNs. The WSN is organised in a hierarchical fashion, with individual components being held accountable for a specific set of obligations. Each cluster contains its own CH, which is responsible for providing services to the many sensor nodes that are situated within that cluster. Every sensor node has a dialogue with the CH responsible for its specific zone. The CH will first perform any necessary processing, then compile the data, and then send it to the base station for transmission. The hierarchical method, which can be applied in a wide range of different sorts of systems due to the fact that it can be used with a number of distinct types of sensors, has been widely adopted. The many different forms of data that can be collected by sensors in a military setting can be use in a broad variety of different ways. Detection of invasions, detection of chemical and biological hazards, and detection of objects in the environment are a few examples of these applications. Another approach to categorise the sensors is according to the physical features that they have, such as the presence of motion sensors, heat sensors, pressure sensors, and chemical sensors. According to the conceptualization of the network, it is the task of the KGC to generate tokens and many other keying materials that the other nodes can use. Tokens are sent from the key generation centre (KGC), which is placed at the base station level, down to the cell hubs (CHs), and then lastly to the sensor nodes. 4 Proposed method When individual nodes in a cluster-based wireless sensor network relocate to a new site, the key management problem for the network becomes an immediate concern. Because of the mobility of the sensor nodes, there is a constant change in the topology of the network. This raises the likelihood that there will be security vulnerabilities in the wireless sensor network. The pre-distribution of a random key is incorporated into our system, and the multi-hop distance-based approach that we have devised is the strategy that we have chosen to adopt to accomplish this goal. This improves energy efficiency and cuts down on the possibility of data packets being lost. 4.1 Key establishment This phase is referred to as phase 1, and it is utilised to produce keys for each individual node that is a component of a cluster. Initial key Ki has already been transmitted to each one of the nodes. Once the primary key, denoted by Ki, has been identified, the master key, denoted by Km, can be produced by combining Ki with a one-way hash function f. After the creation of the primary key, this step can then be taken (hx). A request for a paired key will be sent from Node SNi, which will utilise its master key, Km, to send it to Neighbouring Node SNj. The request will be delivered to the node SNj that is located nearby. After that, the message will be distributed over the network to each node that is a component of it. After the request has been received by the node SNj, the transmission of the pairwise key Kpair to the node SNi will immediately get under way. The pairwise key is produced because of this procedure between any two nodes in the network, regardless of the number of hops that separate those nodes from one another during their communication with one another. In this instance, the value of the likelihood that has been altered in some way is applied to the computation of the constant length of the hash chain. The hash chain, also known as hc, is created with the help of a hashing algorithm that only works in one direction. After applying hc to Ki, the value of the domain key K1 could potentially be increased by an additional I if this is required. Now, the hash function will do its thing and produce n keys, of which at least one will be a part of each cluster. This is how it works. Every cluster chi will have extensive data pertaining to all the cluster nodes. 4.2 Pairwise key establishment The node A will be able to receive the paired key that is necessary to communicate with the target node B once the generation of the master key Km has been completed. Let pretend that node A is trying to establish covert communication with node B by using a paired key Kpair as a means of doing so. Let also make believe that node B is the one who is receiving this covert communication. After the hash chain HC that was established has been finished being created, a pairwise key will be distributed to each node in the cluster. The following paragraphs detail the procedures that must be completed to generate a pairwise key: For A → hxa (hya(ki)) For B → hxb (hyb(ki)) To produce the pairwise key for node A, the following procedures need to be carried out in order: hxa (hya(ki)) is assigned to node A when Xa < Xb and Xa ≤ Xb hxb (hyb(ki)) is assigned to node B when Xa ≥ Xb and Xa ≥ Xb 4.3 Key management This takes place before the sensors are even connected to the network, entails the production and activation of the master key Km. This step is performed before the sensors are even connected to the network. The pre-distribution of keys, which is what makes network security possible, is described in its entirety in Phase 2. Developing a safe connection that can go through a certain number of relays is the objective of the Phase 3 protocol. As part of the first phase, which is referred to as key distribution, the first key, Ki, is generated and pre-distributed to all the nodes in the network before any attempt is made to deploy the network. Amaster key Km will be established at each node SNi by utilising the secret key Ki and the one-way hash algorithm Kh. This process will take place after the previous step has been completed. To ensure that the network is protected, this step will be taken. In the following, the generation of the master key falls under the purview of sensor node n. (1) Km = f(Ki(SNI Di)) After the first stage of the production of the master key, SNi will send an advertisement message to its neighbouring node SNn to communicate its identification data to that node. It will wait for SNn to respond before moving on to the next step in the process. The data is sent to the neighbour node SNn, which then processes it and sends a response to the initial node SNi that includes its own identification data. After that, the process repeats. The master keys Km and Kn are combined with the subkeys SNi and SNn, respectively, to generate a pairwise key that consists of both master keys. The nodes will begin by constructing a pairwise key with their neighbours that are located within one hop from them, and then they will move on to constructing a pairwise key with their neighbours that are located further away from them in the network. The following is how the pairwise key will be computed if the source node is SNi and the target node is SNn in terms of the multihop distance: (2) K = fKiKj, Kk … Kn-1(IDn) 4.4 Authentication If the network needs to add a new node, we will utilise mutual authentication as our method of authentication. If Node A needs to join the network, it will send an authorization request (Auth-Req) to the BS. The BS will then issue a second Auth-Res message that will be encrypted utilising the node A public key once the verification process to ensure that node A is who it claims to have been successfully completed. This will result in the response code ACK1 being triggered. The BS will gain knowledge of the public key, encryption method, and protocol that are associated with the node that was requested while the verification process is being carried out. It is necessary for the node to periodically transmit a Hello signal to re-establish its presence in the network after it has been validated. A particular node in the network will be removed from the network after a predetermined amount of time has elapsed and the BS has not received any data from that node. When a node at a multihop distance makes a connection request that is greater than the transmission limit, there will be a round of mutual authentication that takes place. An authenticating server absolutely needs to have a direct connection to the base station (BS) of the node that is requesting to join the network. In a multi-hop arrangement, Node B will first send an Auth-Req to BS before establishing any kind of connection with Node A. This is Node A is unable to authenticate itself on behalf of BS. Because of this, Node A is unable to authenticate itself on behalf of BS. It performs authentication, activates ACK2, selects the appropriate method and protocols, and encrypts the response message using node A public key before sending it to node B in the form of an Auth-Res message. All of this is carried out after it has been given the request. 4.5 Routing protocol A method of routing that considers energy efficiency is being implemented. To select the path that will lead from the source node to the sink node in the most effective manner, the steps that are detailed below need to be carried out. • To begin the process of correcting the next hop, you must first locate the sink node in the cluster. Only then can you move on to the rest of the process. You are required to make the next hop also a sink node if the sink node can be accessed successfully. • Determine the path that will get you to the destination node in the cluster that is the most time and resource effective if you query each node in the cluster. • It is recommended that the signal strength and the distance be taken into consideration when selecting the next hop in the chain. • During the first stage, when all the nodes are exchanging information with the CH node, the request-reply packet is used to calculate the distance that separates them from one another. • The node that is the next hop node is the one that has the strongest signal strength and is located at the shortest distance from the destination. After the network has been broken up into clusters, the inter-cluster structure will be arranged in a way that considers the reasons the network was developed in the first place. The leaders of the various clusters can communicate with one another or with the base station by way of a chain of intermediate nodes to combine their resources and share information with one another. The transmission range between cluster heads is a configurable parameter that can be adjusted to guarantee a specific level of connectivity while minimising interference when using multi-hop communication among the cluster heads. This modification can be carried out to ensure that the least possible amount of interference is encountered. The definition of connection that is used for inter-cluster communication is based on the multi-hop structure of the network as well as the correlation between the inter-cluster transmission range R, the intra-cluster transmission range r, and the node density. This definition is used when discussing the process of communication between different clusters. However, it is the fact that the theoretical value for connectivity may not be appropriate for a real-time application, namely that the inappropriate inter-cluster range for inter-cluster communication is another inefficient use of energy. The study refers to the fact that the distance between clusters ought not to exceed a few hundred metres in any direction. Let consider the common example of a sensor network. According to the calculations regarding connectivity that were presented earlier, it is proposed that a radio range of 180 m be used for inter-cluster communication. If this were to be done, it would make it possible to create a link that is nearly on par with the direct connection that already exists between all the cluster heads and the base station. We will refer to the range of transmission that takes place between clusters for the purposes of this investigation, where r will stand for the range of transmission that takes place within each cluster. Assuming that the network is dense, we are aware that most cluster heads will serve as nodes in the component of the graph containing cluster heads that has the most heavily connected edges. The study explains the correlation that exists between the value of R, the transmission range between clusters, and the number of edges in a graph that are fully linked. When the clustering procedure has been successfully concluded, the cluster leaders will send Weight messages to all the nodes that are located within a specified radius R. In these messages, the node ID and weight W are both included. When one cluster head receives a weight message from another cluster head, the first thing that it does is compare its own weight to that of its neighbours. This is done to determine whether it has gained or lost weight. If it is not as powerful as its parent node, it will select the parent node that carries the most weight and send an acknowledgement message to the parent node that carries the most weight if it is not as powerful as its parent node. A routing tree will be constructed with a root node that has the largest weight among all cluster heads in the same independent connected component. This node will serve as the starting point for the tree construction. After a predetermined amount of time has passed, this occurrence is going to take place. Once the construction of the routing tree is finished, the cluster heads will distribute a TDMA schedule to all the active nodes in the cluster so that those nodes can start the process of data collection. This will take place after the completion of the routing tree construction. 5 Results and discussions Last Node Dies refers to the moment when the very last node in the network succumbs to its illness and passes away. Both times are utilised in simulation studies to ascertain the lifetime of a network. The time that the first node in the network passes away is referred as the First Node Die (FND) Time. Each of the results of the simulations that are reported here is, unless otherwise specified, the mean of 200 individual tests that were performed using the same group of sensor nodes. These tests were carried out to obtain accurate results. During the simulation, we only calculate the amount of energy that is used by a sensor node radio transmitter, radio amplifier, and data fusion unit. For determining how efficiently the radio hardware dissipates energy, we make use of the same radio model that was employed during the simulation which is shown in Figs. 1–3 . The findings of the simulation indicate that the method that was proposed improves the performance of the network by lowering the amount of money spent on computing, the amount of energy used, the amount of delay time, and the number of lost packets. It was discovered that performance had decreased after a method for single-hop key management was put into action, and this was the case after it was discovered. A significant increase in the number of retransmissions that need to take place because of an attack is required due to the use of a design that only requires one hop, which raises the rate at which packets are lost during an attack. The provision of a single hop key for the establishment of connections with neighbouring nodes and a multi hop key for communicating with a multi hop node is included in the proposed integrated solution for reducing the rate of packet loss and cutting down on the amount of energy that is consumed. This is one of the ways that the energy consumption can be reduced. The use of a one-way hash function enables a reduction in the quantity of processing resources that are necessary for the process of key generation. Using the paired key to assist in the calculation of a one-way hash function Through the use of Ki, we can identify which node in the network is malicious. By utilising the method for key validation, CH will have the ability to ascertain which node in the network is acting in a malicious manner. Each sensor node in the network will be equipped with a verifier, and CHi will see to it that it is kept in the most recent version possible. The results of each key check that is carried out on an individual packet are validated and recorded by the verifier function. If the verification fails for a predetermined number of times, CHi will dispose of the packet. Following that, the malicious node will be removed from the network in a relatively reduced amount of time. 6 Conclusions Within the scope of this investigation, we devise a method of key management that has a low overhead and makes effective use of both the available storage space and the available CPU cycles. This approach to key management in the WSN makes use of an unsupervised learning mechanism and an algorithm for machine learning to accomplish its goals. After running the simulation through a network simulator, the results are analyzed and compared to the most recent and cutting-edge models that are currently accessible. According to the findings of the simulation, the model that was proposed not only offers a higher level of safety and in terms of the amount of energy it uses about 222 J, how efficiently it stores data, and how well it connects to networks. Our long-term goal is to include several of the most cutting-edge security techniques into WSN and IoT application research. The accuracy of their analysis relative to current practises can be shown. In addition, a mathematical model may have been used to analyse the suggested strategy. The efficiency of this system for ensuring the safety of WSN and associated domains can be evaluated by testing it with a variety of novel parameters. This comprehensive review investigates the multifaceted applications of machine learning in materials research across six key dimensions, redefining the field's boundaries. It explains various knowledge acquisition mechanisms starting with supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement, and deep learning techniques. These techniques are transformative tools for transforming unactionable data into insightful actions. Moving on to the materials synthesis, the review emphasizes the profound influence of machine learning, as demonstrated by predictive models that speed up material selection, structure-property relationships that reveal crucial connections, and data-driven discovery that fosters innovation. Machine learning reshapes our comprehension and manipulation of materials by accelerating discovery and enabling tailored design through property prediction models and structure-property relationships. Machine learning extends its influence to image processing, improving object detection, classification, and segmentation precision and enabling methods like image generation, revolutionizing the potential of image processing in materials research. The most recent developments show how machine learning can have a transformative impact at the atomic level by enabling precise property prediction and intricate data extraction, representing significant advancements in material understanding and innovation. The review highlights how machine learning has the potential to revolutionize materials research by accelerating discovery, improving performance, and stimulating innovation. It does so while acknowledging obstacles like poor data quality and complicated algorithms. Machine learning offers a wide range of exciting prospects for scientific investigation and technological advancement, positioning it as a powerful force for influencing the future of materials research. Introduction Machine learning has become a revolutionary tool within materials science research, allowing for quick and precise analysis of complicated material properties, predicting novel materials with desired properties, and optimising fabrication procedures. With previously unseen insights into the molecular and atomic levels of material behavior, its scope also includes improving material discovery, design, and performance prediction [1]. Machine learning techniques have enormous potential to revolutionize how we comprehend, work with, and innovate in materials science as they develop [2]. Machine learning includes various techniques that allow computers to learn and make wise decisions [3]. Models are learned from data with labels through learning under supervision, which enables them to make precise predictions [4]. Unsupervised learning finds structures and patterns in unlabeled data, bringing to light hidden information [5]. Through trial and error, reinforcement learning teaches models to choose actions to maximize rewards [6]. Deep understanding, a subset, uses neural networks to process complex data hierarchies for complex tasks like image and speech recognition [7]. Transfer learning occurs when knowledge is transferred from one job to another, increasing productivity [8]. Probabilities are included in Bayesian methods for modelling uncertainty [9]. For improved accuracy, ensemble methods combine multiple models [10]. The best decision boundaries are produced by Support Vector Machines [11]. Together, these methods drive innovation across industries, advancing artificial intelligence capabilities. Machine learning has sparked a revolution in the synthesis of materials by enabling a diverse array of uses. By using models to predict material behaviors, property prediction speeds up the selection of materials for particular functions [12]. Intricate connections between material structures and desired properties are revealed by structure-property relationships, enabling targeted design [13]. Efficiency is increased by high-throughput screening, which expedites the evaluation of large material libraries [14]. For best results, process optimization optimizes fabrication parameters [15]. Innovation is accelerated by data-driven material discovery, which finds promising candidates in sizable datasets [16]. In material synthesis, generative models produce novel materials with specialized properties that inspire creativity and exploration [17]. Together, these applications redefine the field of materials science, promoting rapid advancement and discovery. Material predictions across domains are revolutionized by machine learning. Property prediction models accurately predict the behaviors of materials, and materials discovery and design quickly produce novel compounds tailored for particular tasks [18]. Critical connections between material structures and desired traits are revealed by structure-property relationships [19]. Manufacturing conditions are adjusted through process optimization, increasing productivity [20]. Extensive material libraries are quickly evaluated by high-throughput screening [21]. Thanks to material characterisation and data analysis, materials science is advanced through accelerated innovation [22]. Machine Learning has transformed image processing, propelling a diverse array of uses. While object identification and localization precisely locate and identify objects within images, image classification accurately labels the images [23]. Understanding is improved by the precise boundaries that are drawn by image segmentation and object recognition. Techniques for strengthening and restoring images improve image quality [24]. Creating lifelike visuals by image generation and synthesis inspires creativity [25]. Understanding and analyzing images delves into intricate patterns for insights [26]. These developments collectively rethink how we process, manipulate, and derive meaning from visual information, revolutionizing the entertainment and healthcare industries. Machine learning innovations in recent years have opened up new horizons for materials research. Microscopic property prediction uses models to predict materials' atomic-scale behaviors, enabling previously unheard-of precision [27]. Complex algorithms are used in material characterization and imaging to extract fine details from extensive data [28]. Data-driven insights are used in material property analysis to unearth hidden correlations and trends [29]. Material discovery and design are sped up through predictive models, producing novel compounds with customized properties quickly [30]. These innovations usher in a transformative era where machine learning reshapes how we perceive and manipulate materials and fuel innovation across diverse fields. While machine learning in materials research has enormous potential, there are also difficulties. Obtaining high-quality labelled data and integrating domain knowledge into models remain challenges [31]. For precise predictions, complex material behaviors and intricate relationships necessitate sophisticated algorithms [32]. Black-box models' interpretability and generalization from sparse data raise questions [33]. It is crucial to consider data usage and bias reduction ethical considerations [34]. Despite these obstacles, machine learning promises quick material discovery, optimization, and innovation [35]. It holds the key to unlocking previously unattainable insights and accelerating materials research, ushering in a new era of scientific exploration and technological advancement by overcoming challenges through interdisciplinary collaboration and algorithmic improvements. The objective of this review article is to offer a comprehensive exploration of the utilization of machine learning in materials research. The first section discusses various machine learning methodologies. The utilization of machine learning in the synthesis of materials is discussed. The substantial contribution that machine learning makes to the prediction of material properties is covered in the following section. The following sections examine recent developments in materials research and the utilization of machine learning to image processing. The paper acknowledges the challenges and prospects in its concluding section. It highlights the need for ongoing research and development to ensure the effective integration of machine learning while realising its exciting potential to influence the direction of materials research. Machine learning methods By utilizing massive datasets and machine learning (ML), which enable computers to learn as they progress, programming has removed many dangers and dead ends [36]. These algorithms can recognize patterns, extrapolate from examples, and change over time [37]. In the literature, various machine-learning approaches are applied to risk assessment [38]. A subfield of computer science called "machine learning" seeks to extract patterns from data to improve performance across various activities [39]. Fig. 1 shows different methods of machine learning. Supervised learning Specific objectives are frequently considered during the design process for materials and machines to respond as desired to applied forces or limitations [40]. Supervised learning stands as the predominant form of machine learning. It operates in two steps. The algorithm identifies patterns within the training dataset, consisting of sample sets and labels. Then it transforms these patterns into a mathematical expression known as a model during the training step. This model is utilized to make predictions about samples it hasn't encountered during the inference phase [41]. New technologies, such as Google TPUs and NVIDIA CUDA, have emerged to provide faster data processing as the quantity and size of datasets accessible for research and commercial purposes continue expanding exponentially. [42,43]. Over the past few decades, computation speeds have been rising quickly in 1 arXiv:2006–12–25 Version 1 (quant-pH) Moores Law, which states that the number of transistors in a compact integrated circuit (IC) doubles roughly every two years, will come into effect on June 22, 2020 [44]. Various techniques provide a function that assigns inputs to the desired corresponding outputs during learning with supervision. The classification problem is a typical example of a learning task with supervision. In this scenario, the learner must approximate the behavior of a function that assigns a vector to one of several classes. This is achieved by analyzing numerous input-output samples of the function [45]. The learning process of a basic machine learning model involves two stages: training and testing. In the training stage, the model is constructed using examples from the training data as input, allowing the learning algorithm or learner to acquire features [46]. Supervised learning is used when labeled data is available for training. It's applied in classification (e.g., spam detection, image classification) and regression (e.g., predicting house prices) tasks [47]. In this learning, models are trained on labeled data, learning the mapping between input features and their corresponding outputs. Algorithms like Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, Random Forests, Support Vector Machines (SVMs), and Neural Networks (in a supervised context) fall under this category [40]. Fig. 2 illustrates the flowchart of the supervised learning process. The Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a renowned learning algorithm for solving classification and regression problems which is also a kind of Supervised Learning. The complexity and effectiveness of prediction models are significantly influenced by SVM parameters like kernel and penalty parameters [48]. A potent machine learning method that applies the principle of minimizing structural risk is called (SVM). In recent years, there has been a significant surge in the application of Support Vector Machines (SVM) for conducting Structural Reliability Analysis (SRA) [49]. The Support Vector Machine (SVM) has the potential to enhance accuracy and generalization when estimating implicit functions, owing to its foundation in the structural risk reduction concept and its adeptness at handling small sample learning [50,51]. SVM has shown superior performance compared to SVR due to its ability to mitigate overfitting in regression and its improved response approximation capabilities [52,50]. SVMs work well in scenarios where there's a clear margin of separation between classes. They are effective for classification tasks, especially in high-dimensional spaces, such as text categorization, image classification, and bioinformatics [53]. SVMs are supervised learning models used for classification and regression analysis. They find a hyperplane that best divides a dataset into different classes. SVMs use a kernel trick to transform data into higher dimensions for better separation when the data is not linearly separable [54]. Y. Liu, Wang, et al. developed Auto-MatRegressor, an automated method using meta-learning for predicting material properties. It streamlines accurate ML model building in materials science by automatically choosing algorithms and optimizing parameters. It utilizes 27 dataset meta-features and performance metrics of 18 common algorithms, incorporating domain knowledge via a materials categories tree. Through experiments on 60 datasets, Auto-MatRegressor efficiently selects algorithms, outperforming traditional methods while being adaptable to various materials discovery and design tasks [55]. Unsupervised learning In material research, solid-state physics, biophysics, and biochemistry, examining the extensive quantities of data produced by atomistic and molecular simulations is becoming increasingly important [56]. The performance gap between supervised pretraining and unsupervised visual representation learning, also known as self-supervised learning, in computer vision is quickly shrinking. Self-supervised learning tries to acquire features without manual annotations [57]. Unsupervised learning is useful when dealing with unlabeled data to find hidden patterns or structures within the data. Clustering (like K-means), dimensionality reduction (PCA, t-SNE), and generative modeling (GANs) are examples applicable to various domains such as customer segmentation, anomaly detection, and data compression [58]. Algorithms in this category aim to find hidden patterns or intrinsic structures in data without explicit supervision. Examples include Clustering algorithms like K-Means, Dimensionality Reduction methods like Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for generating synthetic data [59]. Fig. 3 devotes the uses of unsupervised learning in different fields. Reinforcement learning For learning-based control, reinforcement learning offers a mathematical formalism. We can automatically develop near-optimal behavioral abilities, represented by rules, for improving user-specified reward functions using reinforcement learning [60]. In recent years, deep reinforcement learning (RL) methods have driven significant breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, surpassing human performance in games such as Atari, Go, and no-limit poker [61]. Central to reinforcement learning (RL) is acquiring a behavioral policy that maps states or situations to actions to maximize the cumulative long-term reward [62]. Deep neural networks and RL were not combined until 2015 when groundbreaking research showed how to make deep RL effective in challenging domains like Atari video games [63]. Since then, deep RL has made quick strides toward scaling and improvement, enabling its use in complex tasks like Go and Capture the Flag [64,65]. The latter advancements frequently entailed combining deep reinforcement learning (RL) with architectural and algorithmic complements, including tree search or using slots for episodic memory [66,67]. Reinforcement learning is applied in scenarios where an agent learns to make sequences of decisions by interacting with an environment. It's useful in robotics, game playing (like AlphaGo), autonomous vehicle control, and optimizing processes, where learning through trial and error is necessary [68]. This involves training agents to make sequences of decisions in an environment to maximize cumulative reward. Algorithms like Q-Learning, Deep Q Networks (DQN), Policy Gradient Methods, and Actor-Critic methods are commonly used in reinforcement learning [69]. Deep learning Deep learning consists of interconnected classifiers built on linear regression and a few activation functions [70]. Shallow learning and deep learning are the two distinct stages of machine learning development. Shallow learning will be restricted to no more than a pair of nonlinear feature conversion layers, as opposed to deep learning's limit of four. The most prevalent shallow structures are Gaussian Mixture Models, Logistic Regression, and Support Vector Machines [71–80]. Deep learning's theoretical understanding of the connection between performance, model complexity, and computational needs is still lacking. However, there are compelling arguments for thinking that deep learning depends on processing capacity. This results from the overparameterization problem and how it worsens as more training data are used to boost performance [81]. Deep learning is well-suited for problems with large amounts of data, such as image recognition, natural language processing, speech recognition, and other complex pattern recognition tasks. It excels in learning hierarchical representations from raw data [82]. This encompasses a broad range of algorithms that use artificial neural networks with multiple layers to extract hierarchical representations from data. Some popular deep learning algorithms include Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for image-related tasks, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) for sequential data, and Transformer models like GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) for natural language processing [83]. Transfer learning While traditional machine learning technology has achieved significant success and found practical applications, it still possesses inherent limitations when applied to specific real-world situations. Transfer learning, a compelling approach in machine learning, offers a solution for the mentioned challenge by leveraging knowledge from one domain to another. The concept of transfer learning is rooted in educational psychology, suggesting this field initially influenced it [84]. There are various transfer learning categorization standards. Transductive, inductive, and unsupervised transfer learning are three categories that categorize transfer learning issues [85]. Transfer learning is beneficial when you have a small dataset in the target domain but a large dataset in a related source domain. For instance, in image recognition, you can use a pre-trained model on a large dataset (like ImageNet) and fine-tune it on a smaller dataset specific to your problem [86]. This technique involves leveraging knowledge from one domain or task to aid learning in another. Algorithms like Fine-tuning pre-trained models (e.g., in NLP - BERT, GPT, etc.) and Domain adaptation (adapting a model trained on a source domain to a target domain) are commonly used in transfer learning [87]. Bayesian methods The arrangement of parameters in the population is generated using a simulation-based method through the Bayesian approach in the current study. The ability of Bayesian Propensity Score Matching (BPSM) to account for uncertainty reduces the arbitrary nature of decisions regarding subclassification in the matching process [88]. In the past, Bayesian inference—which offers precise, complete prediction distributions and precisely calibrated uncertainty—was the gold standard for learning using neural networks. Because of the vast complexity of the parameter space, it isn't easy to scale Bayesian inference methods to deep neural networks [89]. Bayesian methods are used to model uncertainty and update beliefs based on evidence. They're suitable for problems involving decision-making under uncertainty, probabilistic reasoning, and in cases where prior knowledge or assumptions need to be incorporated into the model, like in medical diagnosis, natural language processing, and financial modeling [90]. These methods involve using probability to model uncertainty. Naive Bayes is a simple and popular algorithm, especially for text classification. Bayesian Networks and Bayesian Linear Regression are other examples that leverage Bayes' theorem to update beliefs based on new evidence [91]. Ensemble methods To address the shortcomings of single prediction models, ensemble models have gained popularity recently. Ensemble modelling uses data variability to make up for component model flaws like bias and produce a more reliable solution and resistance to Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) model mistakes [92]. Numerous researchers have introduced various methods for forming an ensemble. The foundation of one solution (sol1) was obtaining several training data sets. The authors discussed the utilization of bagging and boosting techniques to create such data, and they highlighted that decision tree-based methods are models that use this type of data. Another approach (sol2) included employing various ensemble members as predictive model members [93]. Machine learning models are becoming routinely used prediction tools, both as solo solutions and as ensemble members. Two frequently used prediction methods are neural networks and decision trees, along with different variants of Support Vector Regression (SVR) [94–97]. Ensemble methods combine multiple models to improve performance and generalizability. They're effective in situations where you want to reduce overfitting and increase accuracy, applicable in various domains like finance (predicting stock prices), healthcare (diagnosis), and recommendation systems [98]. This method combine multiple models to improve predictive performance. Examples include Bagging (Bootstrap Aggregating) with Random Forests, Boosting with algorithms like AdaBoost and Gradient Boosting, and Stacking where multiple models are combined using another meta-model [99]. Machine learning in materials synthesis Machine learning (ML) for materials is rapidly transforming many fields to design innovative materials with higher performance [100] rapidly. Materials have a significant impact on how high technology is developed. Impressive advancements in creating new materials have been made due to the need for unique materials with optimum qualities. Big data may be created and accessed more quickly in the short term using experimental and computational methods. In the meantime, following the traditional eras of scientific advancements driven by experiments, theory, and computational simulations, data-driven research has emerged as the fourth scientific paradigm, primarily due to the increasing scale of available data [101–103]. Machine learning (ML), a field combining statistical learning and computer science, has gained prominence recently as a rapidly evolving subfield of data-driven science [104,105]. ML gives us a new strategy for finding new materials distinct from the conventional method of experimentation involving trial and error. To provide direction for material design, machine learning (ML) makes new predictions by comprehending the data's latent patterns [106]. The creation of numerous top-performing alloy materials, such as titanium alloy, nickel alloy, high-entropy alloys (HEAs), aluminium alloy, shape memory alloy, magnesium alloy, bulk metallic glass alloys (BMGs), nickel-based single crystal superalloys [107,108], and copper alloy, has heavily relied on machine learning (ML) over the past ten years [109–115]. For example, although bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) exhibit unique features like high mechanical strength, low magnetic hysteresis, and strong corrosion resistance, it remains crucial to establish dependable methods for correlating these desired traits with specific compositions [116,117]. The utilization of machine learning in the development of novel materials has expanded. It presents fresh chances to quicken and improve searching for novel materials with desired features. Fig. 4 shows examples of how artificial intelligence is used in material synthesis. Property prediction In machine learning, the term "material prediction" refers to using machine learning algorithms to forecast materials' characteristics, actions, or results. This method entails evaluating and learning from vast quantities of material data to create models that can generate precise predictions about the characteristics of novel and untested materials. The capability to detect molecules or compounds exhibiting one or more features within a predetermined range makes machine learning-based surrogate models especially well-suited for high-throughput screening endeavours. Discovering "optimal" combinations corresponds to finding chemistries on or near the underlying Pareto front. This front represents the best achievable trade-offs among conflicting reactions when a subset of characteristics displays opposing trends or inverse relationships [118]. For a wide range of material classes, including polymers, metals and alloys, 2D materials, ceramics and composites, organic-inorganic hybrids, and multi-component hetero-anionic compounds, machine learning algorithms have been used to find possible non-linear connections involving multiple variables [119–121]. Instances of predicting materials properties with success using machine learning (ML) include estimation of energetics [122–126], stability of phases and arrangement of cations/anions [127–133], defect energetics [134–137], bandgaps [138–142], temperatures at which melting and glass transition occur [143,144], mechanical and elastic properties [145–147], thermal conductivity [148], dielectric properties [149,150], tendency for crystallization [151], catalytic activity [152,153], and radiation damage resistance [154]. Predictive modelling techniques applied to Density Functional Theory (DFT) computations have expedited the discovery of new materials, significantly reducing the search space for upcoming DFT computations and experiments [155]. Since design codes frequently require these qualities, accurate prediction of the mechanical properties of concrete has been an issue. Researchers are pursuing accurate models for forecasting mechanical strength due to the introduction of novel concrete mixtures and applications [156]. Machine learning has a diverse array of uses to predict their property, as shown in Fig. 5 . Structure-property relationship By utilizing self-organizing maps like Kohonen to show structure/property correlations between silver and platinum nanoparticles, data visualization helps comprehend materials datasets and successfully present results [157]. A suitable machine learning approach is utilized to present high-dimensional data within a lower-dimensional framework to make comparing structural features with attributes easier. One such method is the nonlinear dimension reduction method t-SNE which efficiently distinguishes between distinct and comparable items by modelling high-dimensional objects as two- or three-dimensional points [158]. Biological applications and displaying representations from artificial neural networks are only two examples of the many disciplines in which it has been effectively used [159–161]. The Self-Organizing Map (SOM) or Kohonen network [162] is a dimensional reduction technique for materials datasets. It is an unsupervised artificial neural network [163] that preserves the topological connection of the input data while reducing high-dimensional spaces to lower-dimensional regions through mapping. SOMs have been used to present data with multiple dimensions as a single two-dimensional plot for further analysis and generating surface texture maps of nanoparticles as unique material identifiers [164]. To identify structure/property connections in metallic nanoparticles, the article contrasts t-SNE with SOMs. SOMs are proven to be more trustworthy and comprehensible for typical materials research datasets, avoiding distortion [157]. Machine learning algorithms can analyze large datasets of material structures and their accompanying attributes to establish correlations between them. The need for energy has increased in significance on a global scale with the growth of contemporary society. Therefore, there is a pressing need to investigate novel materials for sustainable energy systems. Extended experimental duration and significant expenses make traditional approaches challenging for materials research. Machine learning (ML) is currently emerging as a novel approach in research to transform the discovery of novel materials [165]. Many problems facing the 21st century today, such as sustainability and low-carbon energy, are primarily material-related. To ensure the sustainable growth of human society, materials with precise physical and chemical capabilities for adequate storage and conversion of energy are critically needed [166]. Artificial intelligence (AI) advancement creates fresh possibilities for scientific and engineering advances. Big data and artificial intelligence are "the fourth paradigm of science" [167]. As ML is a potent tool for uncovering the statistical rule concealed behind highly dimensional data, advancements in ML have recently significantly impacted several industries. With the recent expansion of materials databases, the progressive dissemination of ML toolkits like Tensor Flow, Pytorch, and sci-kit-learn, the creation of workflow toolkits like Atomate, and the advancement of algorithms, ML has also recently seen an increase in use in the area of materials science. ML approaches have effectively produced numerous improvements in materials for storing and converting energy, such as battery materials [168–172] and catalysts, by combining them with big data [173–183]. High-throughput screening In machine learning, high throughput screening (HTS) is a data-driven method for handling massive datasets, automating tests, refining models, and finding insightful information. It hastens research by quickly exploring complicated environments, offering data-driven conclusions, and making headway in many applications [184]. A low-cost method for incorporating transition-metal complexes and materials with open-shell configurations into current high-throughput screening techniques was demonstrated using machine learning (ML). To forecast border orbital energies and Frontier Orbital Nature (FNO) based diagnostics, various ML models were trained. These simulations demonstrated that the HOMO-LUMO gap is more ligand-sensitive, whereas the MR exhibits a higher metal sensitivity. These discoveries offer opportunities for individually modifying the two quantities [185,186]. Density functional theory (DFT) is a key methodology for obtaining atomic electrical interactions. High-throughput screening is difficult due to the computationally costly nature of DFT calculations [187–189]. Machine learning (ML) techniques have recently been used to predict material properties [171,190–192] and molecular structures [193–195], significantly reducing the computational cost. High-throughput studies, in which vast libraries of materials are produced and examined, can be guided by machine learning. According to recent literature, chemists and engineers have given machine learning (ML) and high-throughput experimentation (HTE) separate amounts of attention, which has resulted in the creation of potent reactivity models and platforms that can quickly carry out thousands of reactions [196]. Machine learning (ML) can enhance automated high-throughput chemistry testing in three domains: experimental design, route planning, and data processing. New research suggests that machine learning (ML) approaches hold significant potential in addressing the challenge of automated synthesis planning [197,198]. An expansive domain for exploring and enhancing catalysts results from the intricate interactions between various heterogeneous catalyst properties and operating variables that affect how well they work [199–201]. Trial & error testing has traditionally been used to overcome challenges like this, and it has been successful but time-consuming. The screening of many catalyst compositions for ammonia is a prime illustration. Synthesis carried out by Mittasch and colleagues using a preliminary use of high-throughput experimentation (HTE). In general, HTE experiments are effective at efficiently screening a lot of catalysts. However, they can only "hit" a high-performing catalyst in the screened parameter space before they can make a discovery. To direct the tests, it is advantageous to combine HTE approaches with prediction algorithms [202,203] Process optimization In machine learning, process optimization entails using data-driven strategies to optimize processes, simplify workflows, and increase performance, efficiency, and effectiveness. Although complete kinetic schemes for both transport and kinetics in reacting particles are required in comprehensive models of biomass pyrolysis, they are computationally costly and not always feasible for producing sustainable fuels and chemicals [204]. To do this, it is necessary to create comprehensive prediction models that may be used to improve quick pyrolysis methods that turn lignin into valuable renewable fuels and chemicals [205]. As was previously mentioned, the kinetic information in the present comprehensive models is insufficient for this kind of optimization. It has successfully chosen the best model from various training models using dependable and efficient optimization strategies [206–208]. Much effort has gone into maximizing the parameters attained during training, including figuring out the best connection weights and minimizing the training error between projections and related goals. To enhance the precision of the independent Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS), optimization approaches [209,210] are typically utilized for ANFIS models to provide membership functions and related fuzzy rules. The optimum ML model configuration is discovered by reducing the Mean Squared Error (MSE) between target and predicted values using an integer-valued optimization technique based on Genetic Algorithms (GA) [211]. Machine learning and optimization techniques are integrated on the shop floor to enhance production processes. This is possible thanks to advancements in the manufacturing sector's digitalization process and the associated data availability. Additionally, a lack of resources encourages people to adopt new ideas more readily, like machine learning, which helps people conserve time, energy, and resources and prevent waste [212]. Process optimization in high-dimensional parameter space is required to provide a scalable manufacturing method for perovskite solar cells [213]. From discovering molecules and extending through process optimization to chemical manufacturing, machine learning is permeating all aspects of chemistry research and development [214–216]. This has caused the introduction of novel, challenging molecular targets with increased three-dimensionality, necessitating a more extensive and sophisticated reaction toolbox [217]. Constructing these more complex processes later is difficult and expensive, and doing so frequently necessitates optimizing both continuous and discrete variables. Before proceeding with the fine-tuning of continuous variables (such as reaction time, temperature, and stoichiometry), it's common to screen various combinations of discrete variables (such as catalyst, ligand, and solvent) using high-throughput screening (HTS) methods [218–221]. However, the time-consuming 'brute-force' approach to HTS (i.e., testing all potential combinations of discrete variables) is losing appeal due to increasingly complicated synthetic techniques. Additionally, since essential relationships among the combined variables are not considered, sequentially optimizing discrete and continuous variables in the workflow results in a limited understanding of the process [222]. Fig. 6 compares the traditional HTS method and newly developed self-optimization in the Mixed Variable Multi-objective Optimization (MVMOO) approach. Data-driven material discovery Materials discovery and design is a data-driven and systematic approach that uses cutting-edge computational tools, high-throughput screening and machine-learning methods to discover and enhance novel materials with specific desired characteristics [223–227]. This results in affordable and custom materials for various applications, propelling technological advancements. Datasets are required to aid in the detection of target traits, qualities, or unidentified materials when using machine learning to solve material issues. Researchers are turning to machine learning to supplement or partially replace the computationally and empirically costly DFT-based material discovery methodologies [227]. Machine learning in material discovery caters to both big and small datasets using distinct methodologies. With big datasets from materials genomics or high-throughput databases, methods like deep learning, ensemble techniques, and feature engineering thrive, harnessing the wealth of information to predict material properties efficiently. Dimensionality reduction techniques aid in handling numerous descriptors. In contrast, small datasets benefit from transfer learning's adaptation of pre-trained models, active learning, or Bayesian optimization to make data collection more efficient and improve model performance with limited data. Strategies like few-shot learning and meta-learning adapt to scarcity by leveraging knowledge from broader datasets, mitigating the challenges posed by limited data. Tailoring machine learning approaches to these scales optimizes material discovery processes, addressing complexities and scarcities inherent in big and small datasets [228–231]. Driven by the emergence of the big data era, data-centric research rapidly expands across diverse fields as it addresses the demand for faster and more systematic solutions to complex problems [175,232]. These techniques have delivered remarkable outcomes in catalysis, including discovering descriptors facilitating catalyst exploration or extracting patterns from spatially and temporally resolved spectroscopic data related to catalysts [233,234]. Machine learning shows the potential to achieve precision comparable to first-principles calculations while maintaining scalability similar to traditional computations [235]. Although there are many and varied applications of data science, catalysis, a discipline where optimization has traditionally relied heavily on trial and error and luck, offers particularly promising potential [236]. Large volumes of data are necessary for machine learning, and the lack of enough data, particularly experimental data, is the bottleneck of catalytic informatics. In this article, we go through three significant issues frequently faced in research focused on catalysis driven by data, specifically when supervised machine learning is utilized to forecast an experiment's results or the characteristics of a catalyst. These issues, particularly the absence of negative outcomes, are also significant in unsupervised machine learning and reinforcement learning, two other forms of machine learning [119]. In data-driven material discovery, several representative works, such as the Materials Project [237], AFLOW (Automatic FLOW for Materials Discovery) [238], and NOMAD (Novel Materials Discovery) [239], employ methodologies integrating computational materials science and machine learning. These projects harness high-throughput calculations, data aggregation, and predictive modeling to explore material properties efficiently. Within this context, Bayesian optimization emerges as a pivotal methodology facilitating the design process. It assists in optimizing experimental parameters, material compositions, or conditions by intelligently selecting the most informative experiments or simulations. Bayesian optimization operates by leveraging probabilistic models to guide the exploration of the vast parameter or design space, effectively accelerating the discovery of novel materials with desired properties. By employing Bayesian optimization techniques, these initiatives streamline the material discovery process, enabling the identification of promising materials for specific applications or functionalities [240]. Recent advances of machine learning in materials research Rapid advancements in energy, information science, national defence, and other areas have placed significant and varied demands on materials. However, conventional methods for finding novel materials, such as the empirical trial and error method and the density functional theory (DFT)-based method, typically need a lengthy R&D cycle, are expensive and inefficient, and have trouble keeping up with the current state of materials science. Machine learning is one of the most effective approaches to replace repeated laboratory tests or DFT calculations since it can significantly lower computational costs and expedite the development cycle [316]. In recent materials research, machine learning uses historical data to forecast phase diagrams, crystal structures, and properties with faster and more precise predictions. Also, developing interatomic potentials, real-time analysis of experiments, and mapping complex behavior to process variables [317]. Material scientists increasingly employ machine learning to detect patterns and predict outcomes from data [318]. The field of materials science has a rising opportunity to use and expand upon the developments in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) that are reshaping and restructuring sectors throughout the economy. There is reason to believe that these developments will speed up the discovery, creation, and application of novel materials, bringing materials Scientists one step closer to attaining the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative [318]. Over the past ten years, a rapidly expanding discipline has used ML to design and develop problems in materials science and other fields [319]. ML is unquestionably altering the entire paradigm in practically every sector, including science and engineering. Recent spikes in interest in machine learning (ML) may have led some people to believe ML is a universal fix for all problems. In contrast, a human could thrive with sparse data, such as determining from a small set of given data that ML cannot accomplish well. Microscopic property prediction A material's microscopic features, such as its atomic and structural traits, such as the lattice constant, influence its macroscopic performance. As far as we know, machine learning techniques for predicting microscopic properties focus on several factors, such as band energy, lattice constant, molecule atomization energy, and electron affinity. One of the primary hurdles in developing new substrate or buffer materials for semiconductor epitaxy is the lattice mismatch between layers of different materials. The prediction of lattice constants for various element combinations can be expedited using lattice constant prediction. This approach is becoming essential for advancing high technology, as it enables rapid and accurate estimation of lattice constants for numerous unidentified compounds. Machine learning, particularly regression analysis, offers a viable solution for this prediction challenge [321]. Material characterization and imaging Advances in high-resolution imaging techniques have created new opportunities for machine learning (ML) approaches to swiftly and quantitatively analyze functional materials statically and dynamically. This complements traditional methods like modelling, simulations, and synthesis. Historically, characterization focused on qualitative aspects, but contemporary imaging tools, with enhanced resolution and multi-probe capabilities, provide highly detailed quantitative information. Modern real-space imaging methods, such as scanning transmission electron microscopy, scanning tunneling microscopy, and atomic force microscopy, enable direct visualization of atomic-level structures and functional features in complex materials with multiple components and phases [322–326]. Recent advancements in materials imaging and characterization methods enable the acquisition of high-quality data for functional materials under static and dynamic conditions. These developments stem from cutting-edge techniques such as scanning transmission electron microscopy, tunnelling microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and electron backscatter diffraction imaging. Despite its advantages, challenges such as interpretability and data quality persist. Future efforts aim to integrate computational and experimental approaches for more targeted and efficient material research, ultimately enhancing our understanding of material properties. Shi et al. were the first to identify three primary contradictions that hinder the effective application of ML within the material community: conflicts between learning outcomes and domain knowledge, between model complexity and user-friendliness, and between dealing with high-dimensional data and limited sample sizes [334]. This work effectively reconciles the aforementioned contradictions by incorporating domain knowledge from material science into ML methods. It specifically utilizes crystal structure, bond length, and the coordination environment of local atoms as structural descriptors to establish mapping relationships between structure and energy (force). The study explores the fitting of MTPs across various levmax values and identifies their performance in predicting lattice constants, volumes, and mean absolute errors (MAEs) in energies and forces [335]. To tackle these, the study integrates material science expertise into ML methods, employing crystal structure, bond length, and atom coordination as descriptors. It explores various parameters' impact on predictive performance, like lattice constants, volumes, and error metrics. Addressing these challenges is crucial for advancing ML's effectiveness in materials research. Liu et al.'s study introduces a novel method called DML-FSdek for selecting material features in machine learning models, addressing challenges in feature selection. Unlike traditional methods, this approach automates the process, integrating domain expert knowledge to avoid crucial feature omission. It demonstrated success in ten material properties datasets, automatically identifying a smaller yet more relevant feature set. This streamlined approach establishes accurate structure-activity relationships, ensuring interpretable results without sacrificing prediction accuracy. In essence, DML-FSdek achieves a more focused material property representation through Multi-Layer Feature Selection [334]. Fig. 13 illustrates different applications of material property analysis. Degradation detection Machine learning surpasses human judgment in precision and practicality when analyzing materials for purposes like identifying metal corrosion, detecting cracks in asphalt pavement, and assessing the strength of concrete [336–340]. In their work from 1996, Agrawal et al. examined how the properties of an alloy, along with its composition and manufacturing process parameters, are connected. They explored the application of machine learning techniques, including feature selection and predictive modelling, to forecast the fatigue strength of steel. The tempering temperature was shown to be the most significant factor influencing fatigue strength out of the 25 features examined. The process has four steps: The raw data were initially preprocessed with domain expertise. Second, high-relevance features were chosen using ranking-based feature selection techniques. The fatigue strength was then predicted using machine learning algorithms. Finally, Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation(LOOCV) was employed to assess the models' accuracy [341].
